item.title: Introduction
item.description:
Overview

(In)dependence logics are a family of approaches which add (in)dependence relations to first-order logic. The basic semantic framework of dependence logics is Team semantics, which generalize the standard notion of truth and satisfaction to sets of assignments, rather than single assignments.

In this introductory lecture, we will review the history of dependence logics and briefly outline some of their applications. We will then consider mainstream approaches to team semantics and dependence logics and set up the building blocks for the rest of the course.

item.title: Free Choice
item.description:
Free choice inferences pose a challenge to classical treatment of disjunction.

Adam might be in Paris or in London ◊(α ∨ β) 

⇝ Adam might be in Paris and he might in London   ◊α ∧  ◊β

The inference from (1) to (2) is invalid in classical modal logic, but free choice inferences are quite pervasive in natural language. We will consider some of the previous approaches (Zimmermann 2000, Fox 2007, Goldstein 2019) and then examine how the Bilateral State Based Modal Logic (BSML) developed by Aloni (2021) solves this problem.

item.title: Modified Numerals
item.description:
Overview

Modified numerals are expressions like at least n and more than n. It is often assumed that superlatives modifiers give rise to ignorance inferences, while comparative modifiers do not.

(1) John has at least four children.

(2) John has more than three children.

While (1) gives rise to an ignorance inference (the speaker does not know how many children John has), the same inference is more difficult to get in the case of (2). This is surprising, since these expression are considered equivalent in traditional accounts of quantified expressions (e.g. generalized quantifiers).

In this class, we will examine previous approaches to modified numerals and ignorance effects (Geurts & Nouwen 2007; Nouwen 2010; Nouwen 2015). We will then present a first-order version of the BSML system presented in Class 2 (Aloni & van Ormondt 2021) and analyze how this account deals with cases like (1).

item.title: Indefinites & Exceptional Scope
item.description:
Indefinites can escape the boundaries of syntactic islands and ‘exceptionally’ project their existential force out of them. (1a) admits a reading where there is one professor s.t. every student read the paper she wrote. To obtain such reading, the existential must take scope over the determiner phase which governs the relative clause. Note the different scope behavior in case of a universal quantifier (1b), where every must be interpreted narrowly.

(1) (a) Every student read the paper that a famous professor wrote. (∃ > ∀)

(b) A student read the paper that every famous professor wrote. *(∀ > ∃)

We will examine several approaches to the problem, including referentialist (Fodor & Sag 1982), functional (Reinhart 1997; Kratzer 1998) and dynamic accounts (Charlow ?). We will then illustrate how dependence logics approaches (Brasoveanu & Farkas 2011) account for scope relationships and deal with cases like (1a).

item.title: Marked Indefinites
item.description: Typological research (Haspelmath 1997) showed that marked indefinites have a rich functional variety. In this lecture we will be mostly concerned with specificity (specific vs non-specific) and epistemic readings (known vs unknown). We will review the typological landscape of indefinites and examine the semantics proprieties of specific, non-specific and epistemic indefinites. We will then consider Aloni & Degano (2021)’s work, which provide a comprehensive framework to analyze such contrasts using tools from dependence logics and team semantics.
